prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Reglet and Furniture

At gloam, the stickful letters strayed
Click-rang in girded brass;
Reglets hummed; the furniture swayed,
Thunk-thrum the forme in brass.

"Mind the Furnivex," said Case-Old,
"It swallows slips of lead;
It gnaws the reglet-hold," he told,
"And spits the letters dead."

I took my quoincle, bodkin bright,
Click-tack the quoins would bind;
I proofed my nerve by candlelight,
A sortsman's craft in mind.

From galley-gloom the Furnivex
Came hiss and clack and squeak;
Its sortstriped tongue did curl to vex,
Squeak-scritch: its iron squeak.

I sprang with bodkin, quoincle-key,
Whirr-whack, it gave a whirr.
I pressed its neck to reglet-lee,
Snip-snap, a dying whirr.

Back through the lanes of ink and lead,
I bore the beak askew;
Reglets purred; the formes were soft-led,
Case-Old cried "Good for you!"

At gloam, the stickful letters stayed,
Click-rest in girded brass;
Reglets smiled; the furniture stayed,
Thrum-thunk, the forme in brass.
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title "Reglet and Furniture" is present as a non-empty line before first stanza.</C1_think>
<C2_think>8 stanzas total, all quatrains (4 lines each), stanza count is 8 within 5-8 range.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Checked meter pattern across quatrains: line lengths alternate roughly long/short in >60% (~6/8) stanzas with ≥2 content-word difference, satisfying echo of ballad meter.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme mostly on lines 2 and 4: many stanzas rhyme or slant rhyme (e.g., brass/dead, mind/squeak, lee/whirr, askew/you). No AABB pattern dominance; mostly ABCB or similar. ≥60% stanzas have (2,4) rhyme.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza repeats partial phrasing and content words from first stanza: "At gloam," "stickful letters," "girded brass," "forme in brass," but no clear repeated refrain or exact phrase repetitions beyond these content words. At least 2 repeated content words/phrases in final stanza echo first stanza, so ring composition criterion met.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition present in second stanza: "Mind the Furnivex," with warnings about what it does (swallows slips, gnaws). This functions as an admonition/caution to protagonist before encounter.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation before encounter: protagonist takes "quoincle, bodkin bright," and "proofed my nerve by candlelight," indicating preparation and resolve.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter visible: stanza 5 depicts "From galley-gloom the Furnivex / Came hiss and clack and squeak," showing arrival of adversary and confrontation beginning.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive action present in stanza 6: "I sprang with bodkin, quoincle-key," with onomatopoeic bursts "Whirr-whack," "Snip-snap," followed by "a dying whirr," implying slaying or disabling the adversary.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return/celebration in stanza 7 and 8: "I bore the beak askew;... Case-Old cried 'Good for you!'" and the final stanza's calm peaceful status shows triumphant return and acknowledgement.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Invented coinages counted: Reglet, Furnivex, quoincle, sortstriped, squeak-scritch, sortman's, reglet-lee, bodkin, forme, stickful, click-rang, etc. >8 coinages apparent, well above threshold.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza has ≥1 coinage: various stanzas contain invented words like "Click-rang," "Furnivex," "quoincle," "sortstriped," "Snip-snap," "whirr-whack," "girded," so distribution is broad.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Central creature/entity named: Furnivex, a non-canonical entity, is the adversary, central to the action and encounter.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeic bursts present: "Click-rang," "Thunk-thrum," "hiss and clack and squeak," "Squeak-scritch," "Whirr-whack," "Snip-snap," "thrum-thunk" - more than two clear onomatopoeic bursts.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance visible in multiple stanzas: stanza 1 "stickful letters strayed / Click-rang in girded brass," stanza 4 "sortstriped tongue," "squeak-scritch," stanza 6 "bodkin, quoincle-key," and others show clear within-line repetitious consonants beyond incidental.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc order follows canonical: warning ("Mind the Furnivex"), preparation (taking "quoincle"), encounter (Furnivex arrival), decisive act (bodkin attack), and return (bearing its beak, praise from Case-Old).</C16_think>
<C17_think>No verbatim canonical lines from original Jabberwocky appear; all lines original or paraphrased creatively without exact canonical repeats.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical token count low (near zero): no words from canonical lexicon visible; all coinages or standard English words; canonical tokens ≤8 (likely zero).</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable patterns roughly mirror Jabberwocky's ~8/6 longer/shorter lines in every stanza, e.g. lines 1 and 3 more syllables than 2 and 4, syllable counts mostly in 8-9 and 5-7 ranges consistently.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety is good: repeated rhymes not overused; few repeated end words (e.g. brass), but no exact end word reused >2 times aside from ring echo. Good rhyme variety across stanzas.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No overuse of single content word detected; words are mostly distinct; no word appears over 5 times or >8% of content words outside ring echo.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages show at least 4 distinct roots: e.g. "reglet," "furnivex," "quoincle," "sortstriped," "click-rang", suffixes or roots not dominated by one pattern >50%, indicating variety.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Poem addresses given topic of a conflict/adversary narrative with creature adversary, preparation, slaying, celebration; topic clearly matching Jabberwocky-like poem style with new setting and entities.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Implied subtext of overcoming mechanical adversary (Furnivex as a machine/devouring letters) with themes of diligence, craftsmanship, order vs chaos is coherent and detectable through metaphor of printing/composing context.</C24_think>
</think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "The Bluscrue in the Movement" is present and non-empty before first stanza.</C1_think>
<C2_think>All stanzas are quatrains (4 lines) and there are 8 stanzas total, which fits within 5–8.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Meter alternation resembling ballad meter: majority stanzas show alternating longer/shorter lines with at least 2 content-word difference (about 5 out of 8 stanzas); thus ≥60% met.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme in lines 2 and 4 in ≥60% stanzas is present with some slant rhymes and no evidence of AABB dominance; variety appears adequate.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza echoes the first stanza closely with multiple repeated content phrases ("gearlings twine/within the case", "burnish-grace", "tick-tack the mainspring"); ring composition confirmed.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition present in 2nd stanza with "Mind, child of cogs, the Bluscrue’s guile; its threadling teeth will keenly bite"; clear warning to protagonist.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation occurs in 3rd stanza enumerating tools ("I took my loupe and lever-knife; a clicker-pick, adjuster-wheel; my oiler-pen, my pegwood life") and resolving mindset; preparation confirmed.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter happens in 4th and 5th stanzas describing meeting the Bluscrue in the gearglow wood and its movement ("Hush—whirr-whirr—out the Bluscrue wound"), clear confrontation present.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive action in stanza 6: "Click-clack! I set the steadfast stake; the springblade sang ker-ching ker-ching; I threaded through its twisty wake, and snipped the scuttle-spring to sting." This is a clear decisive action resolving tension.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration in stanza 7 and final stanza: "The Bluscrue slumped; its buzz unspun; the gearglade breathed; the beat begun; I bagged the boltling..."; and peaceful closing in 8th stanza; return and calm reaffirmed, celebratory tone mild but present.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Invented coinages include: Bluscrue, gearlings, burnish-grace, pivot-pins, threadling, glimmergrub, loupe, clicker-pick, adjuster-wheel, oiler-pen, pegwood life, gearglow, bobbled, lever-lash, scuttle-spring, boltling; well over 8 distinct coinages present.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least one coinage or invented compound word; breadth of neologisms well spread.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Non-canonical creature named "Bluscrue" is central antagonist, not referencing Jabberwock or canonical creatures.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeic bursts like "tick-tack," "whirr-whirr," "click-clack," "ker-ching ker-ching" appear clearly at least twice; requirement met.</C14_think>
<C15_think>At least two stanzas show clear alliteration and consonance: e.g. “burnish-grace,” “pivot-pins,” “springblade sang ker-ching ker-ching,” “threadling teeth,” “gearglade breathed”; ample consonance/alliteration present.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc order is respected: warning in 2nd stanza → preparation in 3rd → encounter in 4th and 5th → decisive action in 6th → return/celebration in 7th and 8th; canonical narrative sequence kept.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No lines match exactly any canonical poem lines; wording unique throughout.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens used very sparingly or not at all; mostly new coinages; ≤8 canonical tokens—likely zero here.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable count per line approximates Jabberwocky pattern: longer lines roughly 8–9 syllables, shorter lines roughly 5–7 syllables; consistent across stanzas.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme endings (2,4) appear varied across stanzas with no end word repeated more than twice, excluding ring echoes; sufficient rhyme variety.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No single content word is overused to an excessive degree; lexicon diversity maintained well outside of ring echo.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages derive from various root morphemes, not dominated by one suffix or affix; more than 4 distinct coinage roots noted.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Topic is coherent and sustained on a similar subject: a mechanical/clockwork creature (Bluscrue) and its defeat, echoing the theme of the Jabberwocky poem about a quest and foe.</C23_think>
<C24_think>The poem conveys underlying motifs of order vs. chaos, care and skill in craftsmanship, and triumph, suggesting a coherent subtext beyond simply narrative action.</C24_think>
</think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title is present and non-empty before the first stanza: "Murmuration over Stubble".</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 7 stanzas, each with 4 lines (all quatrains), and total stanza count is between 5 and 8. Meets criteria.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Lines alternate length with longer and shorter lines detectable in most stanzas (>60%): e.g., line 1 longer (≈9 syllables), line 2 shorter (~6-7); alternating pattern mostly holds.</C3_think>
<C4_think>In ≥5 of 7 stanzas, lines 2 and 4 rhyme or slant rhyme (e.g. ground/around, day/away, twine/long, thrumm/humm, enthroned/storm, swish/fish, pail/round). No obvious AABB dominance, mostly ABCB rhyme. Rhyme scheme is appropriate.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza roughly echoes first stanza in setting and some phrases (dusk, stubble fields, whirrs/whorls/whirrful whorls woven round) - ≥2 repeated content words/phrases; clear ring composition.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early stanza includes admonition/warning: "Take heed, my seed," and description of the Murmurlord as perilous; functions as an admonition analogous to "Beware ...".</C6_think>
<C7_think>There is clear preparation: protagonist is given a tool ("windspoke, willow-strong") and counsel ("prime pulse and pace; keep heart-song long"); this is before confrontation.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter present: protagonist confronts the Murmurlord, described as a named creature "Mask-of-Many, murk-enthroned," appearing with sound effects ("crackled: krr; bleak brr; low drone").</C8_think>
<C9_think>There is a decisive action resolving central tension: "I winded wide the windspoke’s arc, and split the swirls with swish-a-swish; the Murmurlord unstitched its dark, fell featherfirst in flinder-fish." - decisive slaying act.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration in last but one stanza: "Home strode I ... Old Grange cried out, 'O harvest-dream!' and beat his bowl with spoon and pail." Jubilation is clear.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Coinage count: distinct invented coinages include hushwinds, sable-skein, whirrs, whorls, flitter-change, gritglebe, stubblestems, duskdrift, soot-braid, skirl, hitch, flisk, whush, humm, outcurled, Mask-of-Many, murk-enthroned, crackled sounds (krr, brr), swish-a-swish, flinder-fish, featherfirst, token-tale, harvest-dream, whirrful; easily ≥8 distinct coinages.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least one clear coined term or sound word (examples noted above per stanza). Meets criterion.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Non-canonical creature named and central: "Murmurlord" and further "Mask-of-Many" as a named enigmatic creature, distinct from the canonical creatures. Yes.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia present: "krr; bleak brr; low drone," "swish-a-swish," "crackled," "thrumm," "skirl," "whush," "humm" provide multiple onomatopoeic bursts (≥2). Yes.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance beyond incidental present in several stanzas: "hushwinds combed the furrowed ground," "prime pulse and pace; keep heart-song long," "stubblestems went scritch," "duskdrift droned a throaty thrumm," "fell featherfirst in flinder-fish," "beat his bowl with spoon and pail." Clear alliteration in multiple stanzas (≥2).</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc order valid: warning first stanza 2, preparation stanza 3, encounter stanza 5, decisive act stanza 6, return/celebration stanza 7, ring echo stanza 8. Narratively correct arc order.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No lines match exactly lines from canonical poem; all original wording. Yes.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical token use minimal to none — no canonical nonsense words or names like "Jabberwock" or "vorpal" present; new coinages dominate; canonical tokens ≤8 (likely zero). Yes.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable counts per line match Jabberwocky pattern of ~8–9 syllables for longer and ~5–7 for shorter lines in each quatrain stanza: sample counts support consistency in pattern in every stanza. Yes.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety good: no rhyme end word reused >2 times except subtle echo in ring stanza; rhymes vary across stanzas. Yes.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No lexical content word is overused (>5 times). Lexical diversity seems high, no repeated dominant word outside ring echo. Yes.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages show variety with multiple distinct roots, e.g., multiple different coined roots like murmur-, stubble-, dusk-, flinder-, grit-, hush-, skirl-, whush-, flisk-, several suffixes; no suffix >50% coinages. Yes.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Poem clearly addresses an analogous topic: an invented mystical/creature hunt and slaying in a natural folkloric setting, clearly within the style and spirit of an original Jabberwocky-like poem (do not require same creature, but similar theme). Yes.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Poem has subtext: likely speaks to harvest, challenge vs nature, rite of passage, struggle and protection; coherent implied motif of man vs ominous creature, perseverance, and renewal. Yes.</C24_think>
</think>
